paragraphs.text:
# A LITTLE BIT OF HISTORY

- ***Ancient Era***: Data was stored as a simple file(or a collection of files)
- ***1960s***: Primitive databases come to existence(e.g. Files stored in folders indicating a category)
- ***1970s***: Relational Data Model and Relational Databases emereged!
- ***1980s***: RDMS took the world, Data Analytics invented, Complex Data Models!
- ***1990s***: Data Warehousing, Knowledge Discovery in Databases, Data Mining!
- ***2000s***: World after internet, Web Data and technologies!, Data Science!, Big Data!
- ***2010s***: NoSQL, Hadoop, Scalable Systems, Cloud Computing!
- ***Now***: Deep Learning, Strong AI, Singularity is Knigh!

msg.data:
A LITTLE BIT OF HISTORY

  • Ancient Era: Data was stored as a simple file(or a collection of files)
  • 1960s: Primitive databases come to existence(e.g. Files stored in folders indicating a category)
  • 1970s: Relational Data Model and Relational Databases emereged!
  • 1980s: RDMS took the world, Data Analytics invented, Complex Data Models!
  • 1990s: Data Warehousing, Knowledge Discovery in Databases, Data Mining!
  • 2000s: World after internet, Web Data and technologies!, Data Science!, Big Data!
  • 2010s: NoSQL, Hadoop, Scalable Systems, Cloud Computing!
  • Now: Deep Learning, Strong AI, Singularity is Knigh!

paragraphs.text:
# WHAT DATA MINING IS ALL ABOUT?

***Let's define DM just by mentioning a few things people say is DM instead of what actually it may be!:***  

- Data mining is the computing process of discovering patterns in large data sets involving methods at the intersection of machine learning, statistics, and database systems (Source: Wikipedia)
- The extraction of hidden predictive information
- Transforming data and information to knowledge
- Finding patterns in the data
- An inter-diciplinary field sub-field of computer science
- A process involving Pre-processing, Data Mining, and Results Validation!:0)

msg.data:
WHAT DATA MINING IS ALL ABOUT?

Let’s define DM just by mentioning a few things people say is DM instead of what actually it may be!:

  • Data mining is the computing process of discovering patterns in large data sets involving methods at the intersection of machine learning, statistics, and database systems (Source: Wikipedia)
  • The extraction of hidden predictive information
  • Transforming data and information to knowledge
  • Finding patterns in the data
  • An inter-diciplinary field sub-field of computer science
  • A process involving Pre-processing, Data Mining, and Results Validation!:0)
PYRAMID OF DATA HIERARCHIES

paragraphs.text:
# A FEW USEFUL TERMS

- ***Anomaly Detection***: The identification of unusual data records, that might be interesting or data errors that require further investigation.
- ***Association Rule Mining***: Searches for relationships between variables. For example, a supermarket might gather data on customer purchasing habits. Using association rule learning, the supermarket can determine which products are frequently bought together and use this information for marketing purposes.
- ***Clustering***: Is the task of discovering groups and structures in the data that are in some way or another "similar", without using known structures in the data.
- ***Classification***: Is the task of generalizing known structure to apply to new data.
- ***Regression***: Attempts to find a function which models the data with the least error that is, for estimating the relationships among data or datasets.
- ***Summarization***: Providing a more compact representation of the data set, including visualization and report generation.

msg.data:
A FEW USEFUL TERMS

  • Anomaly Detection: The identification of unusual data records, that might be interesting or data errors that require further investigation.
  • Association Rule Mining: Searches for relationships between variables. For example, a supermarket might gather data on customer purchasing habits. Using association rule learning, the supermarket can determine which products are frequently bought together and use this information for marketing purposes.
  • Clustering: Is the task of discovering groups and structures in the data that are in some way or another “similar”, without using known structures in the data.
  • Classification: Is the task of generalizing known structure to apply to new data.
  • Regression: Attempts to find a function which models the data with the least error that is, for estimating the relationships among data or datasets.
  • Summarization: Providing a more compact representation of the data set, including visualization and report generation.
